title: Wetherspoons doormen eject wheelchair bound MS sufferer after mistaking symptoms for being drunk
text:
News Wetherspoons doormen eject wheelchair bound MS sufferer after mistaking symptoms for being drunk John Geraghty, 58, blasted the pub chain over their lack of empathy for disabled customers after he was ordered to leave The Bright Helm, Brighton Share John Geraghty, 58, who has MS, was ordered to leave the Wetherspoons pub (Photo: SWNS) Share Get daily   Thank you for subscribing!   
Wetherspoons has apologised to a multiple sclerosis sufferer after he was thrown out by a bouncer who mistook his symptoms for being drunk. 
Former teacher John Geraghty, 58, was ordered to leave the pub in Brighton when his body slumped forward due to a lack of muscle control. 
He was with his carer Ross Scrivener who tried to explain John’s medical difficulties, but was told, “I’m not a medical person” by the doorman. 
The worker ordered the horrified wheelchair-bound MS sufferer out of the pub in front of dozens of other customers last month. Former teacher John has slammed the pub chain over their lack of empathy for disabled customers (Photo: SWNS) John (l) pictured with carer Ross Scrivener, who was with him at the time of the incident (Photo: SWNS) 
Two Asperger’s sufferers were refused entry to the Bright Helm pub last year after also being told they “looked drunk”. Read More 
John blasted the pub chain over their lack of empathy for disabled customers. Wetherspoons doormen mistook John's symptoms for him being drunk (Photo: SWNS) John said the security staff made him feel "terrible" (Photo: SWNS) 
He said: “There’s this perception that if you’re in a wheelchair there’s something wrong with your brain. 
“My condition means that sometimes my body slumps forward and there’s nothing I can do about it. John was ordered to leave The Bright Helm, in Brighton (Photo: SWNS) 
“The security guard was looking at me like I was an embarrassment. He made me feel terrible.” Read More 
Wetherspoons apologised to John, from Barton-in-the-Clay, Beds, and is re-training its staff to make them more aware of MS. Like us on Facebook
